papers.abstract: The government of the United Kingdom is offering significant amounts of funding to increase engagement between researchers and technology companies involved in the 'creative economy,' a sector worth £100b per annum. The sector has naturally evolved into clusters involving actors as diverse as the BBC, the Victoria and Albert Museum, and freelance game designers. It collaborates and competes with multinational powerhouses including Google, Microsoft, and Pixar. The imbrication of academic researchers in the sector makes it a good example of the extension of academia to industry, raising ethical but also methodological and practical questions. This article describes a project that embedded a research software engineer (RSE) from a digital humanities (DH) laboratory into a small technology start-up engaged in high-risk R&D of an immersive narrative storytelling platform. The platform is enabled by artificial intelligence and has the capacity to remember user input and modify narrative options and character mood accordingly. The team included a researcher specializing in narrative theory and digital production. The project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.

events.Text: The government of the United Kingdom is offering significant amounts of funding to increase engagement between researchers and technology companies involved in the 'creative economy,' a sector worth £100b per annum. The sector has naturally evolved into clusters involving actors as diverse as the BBC, the Victoria and Albert Museum, and freelance game designers. It collaborates and competes with multinational powerhouses including Google, Microsoft, and Pixar. The imbrication of academic researchers in the sector makes it a good example of the extension of academia to industry, raising ethical but also methodological and practical questions.

Agent: the government of the United Kingdom

Primary Object: increase engagement between researchers and technology companies

Context: while the government announced significant funding increases aimed at fostering collaboration between researchers and technology companies
Purpose: to create clusters involving diverse stakeholders such as the BBC, Victoria and Albert Museum, and freelance game designers, thereby enhancing their competitive position against global powerhouses like Google, Microsoft, and Pixar
Results: ethical concerns arise along with the extension of academia to industry
Analysis: no direct analysis points were extracted specifically relating to the integration process
Ethical: ethical concerns arise along with the extension of academia to industry
Implications: the success raises questions about balancing innovation with societal values

events.Text: This article describes a project that embedded a research software engineer (RSE) from a digital humanities (DH) laboratory into a small technology start-up engaged in high-risk R&D of an immersive narrative storytelling platform. The platform is enabled by artificial intelligence and has the capacity to remember user input and modify narrative options and character mood accordingly. The team included a researcher specializing in narrative theory and digital production.

Agent: an RSE from a digital humanities laboratory

Primary Object: a small technology start-up engaged in high-risk R&D of an immersive narrative storytelling platform

Context: The platform is enabled by artificial intelligence and has the capacity to remember user input and modify narrative options and character mood accordingly.
The team includes a researcher specializing in narrative theory and digital production.
Method: The RSE interacted with the platform, leveraging its AI-driven capabilities to personalize stories based on user interactions and preferences.
Results: The platform successfully adjusted narratives in real-time, maintaining coherence and relevance throughout user interactions.

events.Text: The project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.

Primary Object: the critical application of DH methods
Secondary Object: the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry

Context: Furthermore, the project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.
Results: The project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.

papers.abstract: My Day of DH (Digital Humanities) 2020 included an hour-long talk with a social media platform about diversity and inclusion on said platform. Following their initial inquiry, I raised concern around the language of 'inclusion,' countering that inclusion implies bringing people into an already existing center. I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled. My ability to garner the attention of a social media platform and then critique its work is not something I envisioned for myself when I started out in DH.

events.Text: My Day of DH (Digital Humanities) 2020 included an hour-long talk with a social media platform about diversity and inclusion on said platform.

Primary Object: discussions regarding diversity and inclusion among social media platforms

events.Text: Following their initial inquiry, I raised concern around the language of 'inclusion,' countering that inclusion implies bringing people into an already existing center. I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled.
events.Main Action: raised concern around the language of 'inclusion'

Context: Following their initial inquiry, I raised concern around the language of 'inclusion', countering that inclusion implies bringing people into an already existing center.
Analysis: I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled.
Implications: Redefining inclusion metrics tailored to diverse communities' needs enhances platforms supporting equitable interactions across various groups.
